Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Situation2: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Story: The bell above the store door jingled as another customer stormed in, her face tight with frustration. I forced a smile, reminding myself to stay calm and friendly, even though the line was snaking past the candy aisle. As a cashier, I was expected to be patient, no matter how rude or upset the customer became. My hands shook slightly as I scanned items, the woman snapping about prices and delays. In the back of my mind, my mother’s words echoed from that morning: “Remember, tonight is the family holiday dinner. It’s tradition. We all have to be there, on time, together.” My shift was supposed to end soon, but with the holiday rush, my manager had already hinted that I might need to stay late. I felt torn—my family would be disappointed if I missed the dinner, especially after all their reminders about upholding our traditions. But here, behind the register, I was expected to put on a cheerful face and help every customer, no matter how long it took. The weight of both roles pressed on me, and I could feel my chest tighten as I wondered how I could possibly meet everyone’s expectations.
